questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right elbow pain for several weeks. The pain has limited his productivity at work as a plumber and worsens with extensor movements such as swinging his hammer. He has tried ibuprofen and over-the-counter pain medications with minimal pain relief. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination the patient has full range of motion of the elbow. There is tenderness to palpation at the lateral epicondyle, and pain is elicited at the right lateral elbow with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. There is no swelling, warmth, or redness over the right elbow joint. Examination of the distal forearm, wrist, and hand is noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Overuse of extensor muscles of the forearm
Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm
Degenerative joint changes at the elbow

questions.solution:
This patient’s elbow pain is reproduced with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. This, in combination with tenderness over the lateral epicondyle, suggests a diagnosis of lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) due to overuse of the forearm extensor muscles (extensor carpi radialis brevis and extensor digitorum communis). Overuse leads to noninflammatory angiofibroblastic tendinosis at the common extensor origin of the lateral epicondyle. This condition is typically seen with repetitive wrist extension activities (such as a backhand stroke in tennis).    

In contrast, pain over the medial epicondyle with resisted finger and wrist flexion suggests medial epicondylitis. Overuse of the wrist and hand flexors and forearm pronators can lead to medial epicondylitis. If left untreated, patients may develop ulnar neuropathy, given the proximity of the ulnar nerve to the medial epicondyle. Treatment options for both conditions include a combination of rest, anti-inflammatory medications, bracing, and physical therapy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inflammation of the olecranon bursa:
Incorrect: Olecranon bursitis occurs secondary to repetitive pressure or friction over the elbow joint. Patients present with posterior elbow pain and swelling of the bursa.  
❌ Radial nerve entrapment:
Incorrect: The most frequent site of radial nerve entrapment lies in the proximal forearm over the supinator and posterior interosseous branch at the radial tunnel. It can lead to numbness and decreased sensation in the hand and weakness in the hand and wrist. 
✅ Overuse of extensor muscles of the forearm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm:
Incorrect: Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm can result in medial epicondylitis, which presents with tenderness over the medial epicondyle.   
❌ Degenerative joint changes at the elbow:
Incorrect: Degenerative joint disease of the humeroulnar joint is uncommon but can present following an injury. Patients present with chronic pain, limited range of motion, and crepitus with flexion and extension at the elbow. This patient has full range of motion at the elbow joint.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right-hand weakness. He works as a mechanic, which involves frequent screwdriver use. He does not report any trauma to his hand. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates weakness with extension of the thumb and fingers of the right hand. There is no weakness with adduction and abduction of the fingers. The patient reports mild pain with resisted middle finger extension. The sensation is intact and reflexes are +2 and symmetrical bilaterally. This patient most likely has an injury to a nerve that courses through which of the following structures?

choices.text: Flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles
Olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus
Superficial and deep portions of the supinator muscle
Humeral and ulnar heads of pronator teres muscle

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a radial nerve (deep branch) injury as it passes through the supinator muscle–likely due to repetitive pronation/supination (use of screwdrivers). The radial nerve enters the forearm anterior to the lateral epicondyle, where it branches into terminal superficial and deep branches. The deep branch pierces the two heads of the supinator, where it becomes the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) and innervates the posterior compartment of the forearm. This nerve provides motor control to the wrist and finger extensors but does not provide cutaneous sensory innervation.    

Injury to the deep branch of the radial nerve at the supinator muscle often results from repetitive pronation/supination, direct trauma, or dislocation of the head of the radius. Patients usually present with finger and thumb extension weakness from loss of the extensor digitorum communis, extensor indicis proprius, and extensor digiti quinti function. Patients with this injury pattern will have preservation of cutaneous sensory function.   



Option Analysis

❌ Biceps and coracobrachialis muscles:
Incorrect: The musculocutaneous nerve courses through the biceps and coracobrachialis muscles. Injury to this nerve at that level can result from shoulder dislocation or humeral fracture and presents with sensory loss over the lateral forearm and loss of arm abduction at the shoulder (>15 degrees).   
❌ Flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve courses between the flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles after traversing through the cubital tunnel at the elbow. Injury to this nerve would result in loss of flexion of the hand and digits rather than loss of extension.  
❌ Olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve courses through the olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus (i.e. cubital tunnel) before passing into the forearm. Compression of this nerve will result in weakness of the hand/digits with abduction and adduction and loss of sensation or paresthesias in the ulnar half of the palm and dorsum of the hand over the fourth and fifth digits on both the palmar and dorsal aspects of the hand.  
✅ Superficial and deep portions of the supinator muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Humeral and ulnar heads of pronator teres muscle:
Incorrect: Compression of the median nerve as it courses between the humeral and ulnar heads of the pronator teres muscle presents with diminished sensation in the lateral thenar eminence and the palmar aspect of the first 3 1⁄2 digits.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis three years ago and is currently taking infliximab. Recently, the patient has been experiencing a tingling sensation in her hands and feet. In addition, she had an episode of eye pain and vision loss that resolved spontaneously. The physician decides to switch this patient to a new medication. Which of the following is the most appropriate option?
questions.solution:
This patient with rheumatoid arthritis is most likely experiencing demyelinating side effects from infliximab use. Anti-TNF agents are well-known to cause demyelinating syndromes including transverse myelitis (most likely responsible for tingling and weakness in this patient’s hands and feet) and optic neuritis (eye pain and loss of vision like this patient). Patients with severe side effects from TNF inhibitors should be switched to another class of medications.

Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits interleukin-12/23 and can be used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, especially in patients who do not respond to TNF inhibitors or are intolerant to them (like this patient). It can also be used in the treatment of psoriasis and Crohn’s disease.

Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that works by binding to and inhibiting IL-12/23. IL-12 is an inflammatory mediator that is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn’s disease, and psoriasis, as well as other inflammatory disorders. It activates T-cells and induces the differentiation of T-helper cells.  In addition, it also helps in the formation of granulomatous inflammatory response along with other cytokines (e.g., Interferon-Gamma, Tumor Necrosis factor). Therefore, ustekinumab inhibits T-cell-mediated inflammatory response and decreases joint damage in rheumatoid arthritis. In Crohn’s disease, ustekinumab decreases granuloma formation and reduces bowel wall thickening.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ustekinumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Adalimumab:
Incorrect: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF monoclonal antibody like infliximab, and it shares the same side effects. Since this patient is not tolerating TNF antagonists, another class of drug should be used.  
❌ Certolizumab:
Incorrect: Certolizumab is also a TNF antagonist, and should be avoided in this patient since she is having severe side effects from another medication in this class.  
❌ Naproxen:
Incorrect: Naproxen is an NSAID. It is used in rheumatoid arthritis patients to alleviate the pain and stiffness, but it does not slow the joint destruction; therefore, it is not an appropriate alternative for infliximab.  
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Like NSAIDs, steroids do not alter disease progression in rheumatoid arthritis and are only used to alleviate the pain and stiffness.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of years of chronic low back pain that improves with exercise and worsens with rest. He reports morning stiffness in the lower back that lasts for over two hours. On physical examination, the patient has decreased chest expansion and limited spinal mobility. Laboratory findings include an elevated ESR and C-reactive protein. X-ray of the spine reveals a “bamboo spine.” Which of the following additional X-ray findings would be expected with this patient's likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of chronic low back pain with reduced spinal range of motion, along with sacroiliac joint tenderness and the x-ray finding of a “bamboo spine” is consistent with ankylosing spondylitis. This diagnosis is further supported by the presence of elevated inflammatory markers. An additional radiologic finding associated with ankylosing spondylitis is fusion of the sacroiliac joints.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic, inflammatory condition that primarily affects the spinal and sacroiliac joints. Plain films can show bony changes that result from the disease. Sacroiliitis may be the first radiological finding seen in patients. It is diagnosed by finding loss of definition in the articular surfaces of the sacroiliac joints with erosions and subchondral sclerosis. Eventually, the joint space may disappear completely.

In the spine, vertebral bodies may appear “squared” from periosteal proliferation of new bone. Additionally, syndesmophytes (vertical bony growths) can be seen as ossification of the annulus fibrosis occurs. These syndesmophytes cause fusion of the vertebral bodies, limiting the spine’s range of motion and producing the unique “bamboo spine.”

In addition to x-rays, laboratory studies are often performed during the workup for ankylosing spondylitis. Inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP are usually elevated. Patients may also be positive for HLA-B27. Additional studies should be sent to rule out other autoimmune and inflammatory conditions that affect the joints (depending on the clinical presentation), such as antinuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factor, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, Lyme serology, and joint fluid analysis.

Erosions and subchondral sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints in ankylosing spondylitis  
 Image courtesy of Eva M. Escobedo, MD; B. J. Manaster, MD, PhD, FACR. STATdx. © Elsevier 2023. Image reused with permission.  
“Shiny corners” and complete syndesmophytes contribute to squaring of the vertebral bodies in ankylosing spondylitis.
 
 Image courtesy of Eva M. Escobedo, MD; B. J. Manaster, MD, PhD, FACR. STATdx. © Elsevier 2023. Image reused with permission.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fusion of the sacroiliac joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Widening of the intervertebral foramina:
Incorrect: Widening of the intervertebral foramina is not associated with ankylosing spondylitis. This finding can be seen in conditions like neurofibromatosis, where nerve sheath tumors cause expansion of the neural foramina.  
❌ Enlargement of the vertebral bodies:
Incorrect: Enlargement or ballooning of the vertebral bodies can be seen in Paget disease of bone where there is abnormal bone remodeling. It is not typically associated with ankylosing spondylitis.  
❌ Displacement of the intervertebral discs:
Incorrect: Disc displacement and herniation are more commonly associated with degenerative disc disease or traumatic injury. This is not a typical finding in patients with ankylosing spondylitis.  
❌ Widening of the sacroiliac joints:
Incorrect: Widening of the sacroiliac joints is not associated with ankylosing spondylitis, fusion is more often seen.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the primary care office due to 6 weeks of joint pain in both hands. She has joint stiffness lasting 1 hour in the mornings and the pain and stiffness worsens with prolonged inactivity. The patient has also recently developed fatigue and malaise, but she has no fever or weight loss. She has no past medical history and does not take any medication. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational substances and is not currently sexually active. She works as a high school principal. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, multiple proximal interphalangeal joints and metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are edematous and tender to palpation. She has pain when she moves them and her grip is weak, secondary to pain. Initial complete blood work and basic metabolic panel are normal. Which of the following is most likely to be positive and confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 52-year-old patient presents with 6 weeks of polyarticular arthritis affecting the small joints of the hands bilaterally and is associated with morning stiffness and fatigue. Given the finding of synovitis of the hands and no other signs to indicate other autoimmune conditions or septic arthritis, the most likely diagnosis is RA, and a positive rheumatoid (RF) can help make the diagnosis.

Patients with rheumatoid arthritis typically present with symmetric inflammatory polyarthritis involving the peripheral joints, most often the hands and feet. They may also have constitutional symptoms like weight loss, fatigue, and malaise. Patients typically experience prolonged joint stiffness (> 30 minutes) in the morning or after prolonged inactivity, which is a hallmark of inflammatory arthritis. On physical examination, patients will have symmetric small joint swelling and synovitis involving the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints, and metatarsophalangeal joints. Boutonniere deformities ( finger flexed at the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) and hyperextended at the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP)) and swan-neck deformities (proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint hyperextension and flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint may be seen with long-standing diseases. Elevations of ESR and CRP are typically seen and can be used to monitor disease activity. Imaging can show erosions in chronic or severe disease. The presence of rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-CCP (anti-citrullinated peptide) antibodies can help make the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rheumatoid factor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gonorrheal nucleic acid amplification testing:
Incorrect: This test can help in evaluating for disseminated gonococcal infection, which is unlikely in this patient who is not sexually active. Patients with disseminated gonococcal infection typically present with a vesiculopustular rash, migratory arthralgias, tenosynovitis, and arthritis.  
❌ Antinuclear antibody:
Incorrect: An antinuclear antibody (ANA) test should be ordered initially when SLE is suspected. Besides arthritis, this patient has none of the other features associated with SLE, such as malar rash, photosensitivity, alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias.  
❌ Parvovirus B19 serology:
Incorrect: Adults with parvovirus can present with acute polyarthritis involving the bilateral hands. Parvovirus B19 may affect adults who have close contact with young children (e.g. daycare, and preschool teachers) where it can cause, fifth disease with the classic slapped cheek facial rash. This patient works with older children and has a more chronic cause of her arthritis.  
❌ Arthrocentesis:
Incorrect: Arthrocentesis should be performed when there is monoarticular arthritis to rule out septic arthritis, and it can help with diagnosing crystal arthritis. This patient with a subacute or chronic symmetric polyarthritis of the hands is more likely to have RA.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with severe pain in the left foot for one day. There has been marked redness and swelling of the first left toe and top of the foot since yesterday. His past medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis of the knees for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide and naproxen, respectively. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Body mass index is 32 kg/m2. On examination, the patient appears to be in moderate distress due to pain. Examination of the left foot reveals erythema, warmth, and swelling at the first MTP joint and over the dorsum of the foot as seen in the image below. There is exquisite tenderness to light palpation at the first MTP joint and significant pain with passive movement of the first MTP. Which of the following additional historical elements is most likely to have contributed to the underlying condition?
 

Image by Gonzosft is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Germany license, reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of rapid onset severe pain, swelling, and erythema of the first MTP and dorsum of the left foot is typical for podagra or gout of the first digit of the foot. Gout is a common cause of foot pain caused by uric acid crystal deposition in joint spaces and is associated with hyperuricemia. Alcohol consumption is a known trigger. Other common triggers include medications such as diuretics and aspirin; physical stresses such as surgery, illness, trauma, and dehydration; and certain foods including red meat, organ meat, and shellfish. Obesity, biological male sex, increased age, and hypertension are all additional risk factors for gout.

When evaluating a patient with foot pain, there should be a focus on differentiating traumatic, infectious, inflammatory, and neuropathic etiologies. Patients with foot pain caused by trauma will usually recall an inciting event and report pain that is worse with activity and improved with rest. Patients with foot pain caused by infection may have a history of diabetes mellitus, smoking, or an immunocompromised state, as well as systemic symptoms such as fever, chills, or myalgias, with or without local skin trauma. Numbness and tingling may precede the onset of neuropathic foot pain, which patients describe as lancinating, electrical, or radiating pain, burning, or coldness. Other common causes of foot pain include osteoarthritis, crystal arthropathy, rheumatoid arthritis, hallux valgus, bone pain; and dermatologic conditions such as plantar warts, tinea, and mechanical keratosis, also known as corns and calluses.    

Option Analysis

✅ Excessive alcohol consumption:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Local bacterial infection:
Incorrect: Local bacterial infection does not directly cause gout. It can result in cellulitis which can present similarly to gout. However, systemic infections can induce gouty flares. 
❌ Vegan diet :
Incorrect: Dietary choices can contribute to gout; however, increased red meat and seafood consumption are associated with gout flares. A vegan diet would reduce the likelihood of gout.  
❌ Long-distance running:
Incorrect: Overuse injuries from long-distance running can contribute to conditions such as stress fractures, tendonitis, and plantar fasciitis, but running or other activities are not typically associated with gout.  
❌ Naproxen use:
Incorrect: Naproxen and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are used to treat gout. Medications including Thiazide diuretics can lead to gouty flares.
